show.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The man grinned, showing bad teeth.
The children proudly showed me their presents.
Show your ticket to the woman at the entrance.
show.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to provide facts or information that make it clear that something is true, that something exists, or that something has happened
show.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Figures showed a 9% rise in inflation.
Gary has shown his faith in the club’s future by agreeing to stay on.
The Polish economy began to show signs of recovery.
It just goes to show (=proves) how much people judge each other on how they look.
Several studies have shown that aggressive toys lead to bad behaviour.
studies/evidence/research etc shows
Mike needed a copy of the will to show that the books had been left to him.
show (that)
We have shown our critics that we can succeed.
show somebody (that)
This document shows how to oppose bad decisions about new housing.
show how
She just wants a chance to show what she can do.
show what
Charles showed himself to be a fine leader.
show somebody/something to be something
The campaign has been shown to be a waste of money.
be shown to be/do something
The new treatment has been shown to reduce the number of deaths.
be shown to be/do something
show.translation[0].definitions[1].note_: In written English, people often prefer to use indicate, which sounds more formal than show:
The latest statistics indicate that the country is falling deeper into recession.
This research demonstrates the need to treat cancer early.
In scientific contexts, they often prefer prove or demonstrate, which sound more definite:
This research demonstrates the need to treat cancer early.
show.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to let your feelings, attitudes, or personal qualities be clearly seen
show.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Think positively and show some determination.
She had learned not to show her emotions.
It was the sound a man might make when in pain but trying not to show it.
Mary showed great interest in the children.
show.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to explain to someone how to do something, by doing it yourself or using actions to help them learn
show.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Show me how the gun works.
Maureen showed Peter how to feed the young animals.
show somebody how to do something
Can you show Lucy the way to slice onions?
show.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: if a picture, map etc shows something, you can see it on the picture, map etc
show.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: I want a photograph that shows his face.
The map shows the main rivers of the region.
show.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to go with someone and guide them to a place
show.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Can you show Mrs Davies to the bathroom?
I can show myself out  (=out of the office or house).
Come on, I’ll show you the way.
show.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to let someone see where a place or thing is, especially by pointing to it
show.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Can you show me exactly where he fell?
show.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to make a film or television programme available on a screen for people to see, or to be on a screen
show.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: The film was shown on television last night.
The match was shown live  (=could be seen on television while it was being played).
It’s now showing at cinemas across London.
show.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if something shows, it is easy to see
show.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: His happiness showed in his face.
Her scar doesn’t show, because her hair covers it.
Stephen was worried, and it showed.
show.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: if material shows the dirt or a mark, it is easy to see the dirt or mark on it
show.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: Light-coloured clothes tend to show the dirt.
show.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to have an increase or decrease in something, or a profit or loss
show.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: The price of players is the reason why many football clubs show big losses on their balance sheets.
Recent elections have shown significant gains by right-wing groups.
show.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to put a group of paintings or other works of art in one place so that people can come and see them
show.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: Her recent sculptures are being shown at the Hayward Gallery.
The Whitney Museum was the first to show Mapplethorpe’s photographs.
show.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to put an animal into a competition with other animals
show.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: Do you plan to show your dogs?
show.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: to arrive at the place where someone is waiting for you
show.translation[0].definitions[13].exam: I went to meet Hank, but he never showed.
show.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: let someone see
to let someone see something, especially by holding it out in front of them
Everyone has to show their identity cards at the entrance to the building.
Stephanie showed us her engagement ring.
flash
to show something to someone very quickly
‘We’re police’, he said, flashing his card at us.
Miranda flashed a surprised look into the mirror.
let somebody have a look/take a look
to show something to someone, especially so that they can examine it, repair it etc
If the wound doesn’t get better soon, you should let the doctor take a look at it.
Mike’s good with cars – let him have a look.
reveal
to let someone see or know about something that is usually hidden, or that you want to keep secret – often used about showing your feelings or private thoughts
Suzy looked away quickly in order not to reveal her true feelings.
He lifted the lid of the box to reveal a small snake.
expose
to let someone see something that could not be seen before
The receding tide had exposed huge expanses of sand.
The bear opened its mouth, exposing rows of sharp teeth.
show someone how to do something
to explain to someone how to do something or how something works, especially by doing it yourself
Laurie’s been showing me how to snowboard.
Can I show you how the oven works?
demonstrate
to show how to do something or how something works – especially to a group of people
A qualified instructor will demonstrate how to use the machines properly.
There’s a meeting this afternoon to demonstrate the new software.
guide/take somebody through something
to show someone how to do something, or how a process happens, especially something difficult or complicated
The book guides you through the different stages of starting your own business.
A stockbroker will take you through the minefield of stocks and shares.
show.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a performance for the public, especially one that includes singing, dancing, or jokes
show.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: They’ve come to town to see a Broadway show.
Perry was the star of the show.
show.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a programme on television or on the radio
show.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The senator appeared on the CBS show ‘Face the Nation’.
show.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: an occasion when a lot of similar things are brought together in one place so that people can come and look at them
show.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: Kelly has a show of her latest work opening shortly.
show.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: when you pretend to do or feel something
show.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Susan put on a show of regret all day.
The waiter made a show of wiping the table.
show.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: an impressive scene, especially one that is very colourful
show.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: Maple trees put on their best show in the autumn.
a glorious show of colour in the rose garden
show.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: a competition between similar things or animals to choose the best
show.translation[1].definitions[5].examp: The dog show was being held in the Agricultural Hall.
show.translation[1].definitions[6].defin: something which is being done or organized
show.translation[1].definitions[6].examp: We need to find someone to run the show (=be in charge).
show.translation[1].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 2: a programme on television or on the radio
show.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: Tonight’s show is live from Wembley Stadium.
It’s the BBC’s most popular quiz show.
It’s been a popular game show for years.
She was on the chat show to publicize her new novel.
It’s a real family show, with something for everyone.
appear on/take part in a show
They were trying to persuade Daniel Radcliffe to appear on the show.
He presents his own chat show on ITV.
People of all ages watch the show.
Very quickly, Williams became the star of the show.
show.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: an occasion when a lot of similar things are brought together in one place so that people can come and look at them or so that they can compete against each other
